title: 114_hr3311
content:
The "End Oil and Gas Tax Subsidies Act of 2015" amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend the amortization period for geological and geophysical expenditures from a 24-month period to a 7-year period. This amendment applies to expenses incurred after December 31, 2015. Additionally, the Act addresses the production of oil and gas from marginal wells. The "End Oil and Gas Tax Subsidies Act of 2015" extends the amortization period for geological and geophysical expenditures from 24 months to 7 years for expenses incurred after December 31, 2015. It also addresses producing oil and gas from marginal wells by amending the Internal Revenue Code. The "End Oil and Gas Tax Subsidies Act of 2015" extends the amortization period for geological and geophysical expenditures from 24 months to 7 years for expenses incurred after December 31, 2015. It also addresses enhanced oil recovery credit and intangible drilling and development costs for oil and gas wells. The "End Oil and Gas Tax Subsidies Act of 2015" extends the amortization period for geological and geophysical expenditures from 24 months to 7 years for expenses incurred after December 31, 2015. It also addresses intangible drilling and development costs for oil and gas wells, excluding such costs incurred after December 31, 2015. Additionally, the act repeals the percentage depletion for oil and gas wells. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 removes section 613A and makes conforming amendments to section 45H, defining related persons for tax purposes. The term 'significant ownership interest' is defined as 5 percent or more ownership in a corporation, partnership, or estate/trust. Interests owned by a corporation, partnership, trust, or estate are considered owned directly by itself. The tax code amendments include changes to depletion allowances and references to specific sections. Ownership interests in corporations, partnerships, trusts, or estates are considered directly owned by themselves. The End Oil and Gas Tax Subsidies Act of 2015 makes amendments to various sections of the tax code, including changes to depletion allowances and ownership interests in corporations, partnerships, trusts, or estates. The tax code amendments include changes to various sections such as striking paragraph (3) in Section 776, amending Section 954(g)(2)(D) by adding a clause, and modifying Sections 993(c)(2)(C), 1202(e)(3)(D), and 1367(a)(2) by replacing references to sections 613 and 613A. The tax code amendments involve changes like amending Section 1446(c) by redesignating paragraph (3) as paragraph (2) and applying the amendments to property placed in service after December 31, 2015. SEC. 7. REPEAL OF DEDUCTION FOR TERTIARY INJECTANTS. Part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking section 193. Effective Date: The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015.

SEC. 8. REPEAL OF EXCEPTION TO PASSIVE LOSS LIMITATIONS FOR WORKING INTERESTS IN OIL AND GAS PROPERTIES. Section 9 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 states that the deduction for income attributable to domestic production activities is not allowed with respect to oil and gas activities for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015. Section 199 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include the production, refining, processing, transportation, or distribution of oil, gas, or any primary product thereof. Additionally, the prohibition on using last-in, first-out accounting for oil and gas companies is implemented for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2015. The amendment to Section 472 of the Internal Revenue Code prohibits major integrated oil companies from using a specific inventory method. A major integrated oil company is defined as a producer of crude oil with certain production and revenue thresholds. The amendment to Section 472 of the Internal Revenue Code restricts major integrated oil companies from using a particular inventory method if their average daily refinery runs exceed 75,000 barrels for the taxable year. Controlled groups and common control are treated as one entity, and special rules apply for short taxable years. The average daily refinery runs for a taxable year are determined by dividing the aggregate refinery runs by the number of days in the year. Related persons are defined as those with significant ownership interests in each other. The definition of 'significant ownership interest' includes owning 15% or more of stock in a corporation, profits or capital in a partnership, or beneficial interests in an estate or trust. The amendment applies to ownership interests held by corporations, partnerships, trusts, or estates, considering them owned directly by the entity and proportionately by its shareholders, partners, or beneficiaries. The effective date is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2015, with a special rule for taxpayers changing their accounting method. The taxpayer-initiated change requires consent from the Secretary of the Treasury and spreads adjustments over a maximum of 8 taxable years under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES APPLICABLE TO DUAL CAPACITY TAXPAYERS. Section 901 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to include special rules for dual capacity taxpayers regarding foreign oil and gas income. Any excess amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by a dual capacity taxpayer is not considered a tax. Dual capacity taxpayer is defined as someone with dual roles in a foreign country or possession. The term 'dual capacity taxpayer' refers to a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States, who receives a specific economic benefit from that country or possession. These amendments apply to taxes paid or accrued after December 31, 2015, except where contrary to any treaty obligation of the United States.
